questions.question: When should an elective caesarean section ideally be performed?
questions.explanation: An elective caesarean section should ideally be performed after 39 weeks.It is not done before 39 weeks of gestation as there is an increased risk of:•Complications related to prematurity including respiratory problems• Neonatal adaptation problems such as hypothermia and hypoglycemia

questions.question: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is set to undergo an elective LSCS 2 days later. What is theideal time to administer antibiotics to this patient?
questions.explanation: According to ACOG guidelines, the ideal time to administer antibiotics is within a time period of60 mins prior to the planned caesarean section.Antimicrobial administration before surgical incision has been shown to lower postoperativeinfection rates without adverse neonatal effects, as compared with drug administration afterumbilical cord clamping. A 1 g dose of cefazolin is an efficacious and cost-effective choice.For emergency delivery, antibiotic prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible.

questions.explanation: The above partogram is suggestive of obstructed labour and the definitive management in thiscase is caesarean section. Cefazolin is an efficacious and cost-effective choice for antibioticprophylaxis before caesarean section.According to the partogram, there is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest ofdescent for >1 hour. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heartrate indicating fetal distress. questions.question: You are asked to administer antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis to a patientposted for elective LSCS. What condition does the patient likely have?
questions.explanation: Antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis before surgical procedures is recommendedin patients with prosthetic valves, prior history of endocarditis, and unrepaired cyanotic heartdiseases.Pregnant women at the highest risk for endocarditis are those with cyanotic cardiac disease,prosthetic valves, or both. However, endocarditis prophylaxis is not required if the patient isalready receiving intrapartum prophylaxis with broad-spectrum antibiotics to preventendometritis.Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for atrial septal defect (ASD). The risk of endocarditiswith ASD is negligible. Bacterial endocarditis is associated with unrepaired ventricular septal279defects where antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended. Similarly, prophylaxis for bacterialendocarditis is indicated at delivery for unrepaired patent ductus arteriosus.

questions.question: A 25-year-old obese pregnant woman is scheduled for caesarean section. While going throughher file, you find that she is allergic to penicillin. What is/are the antibiotic(s) you wouldprescribe for her?
questions.explanation: In an obese pregnant woman who is allergic to penicillin, a dose of 900 mg clindamycin with anaminoglycoside is used for antibiotic prophylaxis.In women with significant penicillin or cephalosporin allergy, a single 600 mg intravenous dose ofclindamycin combined with a weight-based dose of aminoglycoside is recommended. For obesewomen, a 900 mg dose is preferred.

questions.question: A woman with preeclampsia presents with haemorrhage at 38 weeks of gestation. You decideto perform a caesarean section and terminate the pregnancy. What is the anaesthesia ofchoice?
questions.explanation: General anaesthesia is the anaesthesia of choice here since the patient presents withhaemorrhage.General anaesthesia may be indicated for emergency cesarean delivery in patients with areassuring airway examination. It is also recommended for patients with severe coagulopathywhere neuraxial anesthesia is contraindicated.Spinal anesthesia is not preferred when the operation is expected to result in blood loss or in apreviously haemorrhaging patient. It is because in such cases the development of severehypovolemia is likely which is a contraindication for this type of anaesthesia.

questions.question: An elective cesarean section is being performed in a primigravida due to suspectedcephalopelvic disproportion. In which of the following abdominal incisions are the rectimuscles transected?
questions.explanation: The recti muscles are transected in the Maylard incision for caesarean delivery which is marked as'2' in the given image.It is a variation of the Pfannenstiel incision in which the rectus abdominis muscles are sectionedtransversely to permit wider access to the pelvis. It is also known as the Mackenrodt incision.The various incisions mentioned in the image are:-Incision '1' Midline vertical incision is made in the middle extending from just below theumbilicus to just above the symphysis pubis. This is used less commonly compared to thetransverse abdominal incision.-Incision '3' Joel Cohen is a straight incision higher than the Pfannenstiel incision. The fascia wasincised transversely in the midline then extended laterally with blunt finger dissection; fingerdissection was used to separate the rectus muscles vertically and laterally.-Incision '4' Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in caesarean delivery. Itfollows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in theskin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis.280This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this,the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gainentry to the peritoneum.Abdominal incisions for caesarean sectionOMARROWMidline verticalMaylardJoel CohenPfannenstiel

questions.question: All of the following are benefits of using a transverse abdominal incision for caesareandelivery in a patient except_
questions.explanation: Transverse abdominal incisions offer a narrow operating space.

questions.question: An elective C-section is being performed in a primigravida due to suspected contracted pelvis.After opening the abdomen through a modified Pfannenstiel incision, the obstetrician makesa low transverse uterine incision. How should this incision be extended?

options.A: By applying lateral and slightly upward pressure with each index finger
options.B: By applying lateral and slightly downward pressure with each index finger
options.C: By applying lateral and slightly upward pressure with each thumb
options.D: By applying lateral and slightly downward pressure with each thumb

questions.explanation: In a C-section, the incision on the uterus can be extended by using lateral and slightly upwardpressure applied with each index finger.If the lower uterine segment is thick, then cutting laterally and then slightly upward with bandagescissors will extend the incision.Note: When scissors are used, the index and middle fingers of the non-dominant hand should beinsinuated between the myometrium and the fetal parts to prevent fetal laceration.

questions.question: The highest risk of uterine rupture is seen with
questions.explanation: A T-shaped incision has the highest risk of uterine rupture among the given options. Among allthe incisions, a previous classical cesarean incision has the highest risk of rupture but it is not anoption here.Overall, the maximum risk of uterine rupture is in patients who have had a previous uppersegment uterine rupture. Women with single prior low-transverse hysterotomy have the lowestrisk of symptomatic scar separation.281

questions.question: An obstetrician performing a C-section exteriorises the uterus before performing uterinerepair. All of the following are true about this procedure except_

options.A: Incision and bleeding points are easily visualized and repaired
options.B: Relaxed/atonic uterus can be recognized quickly and massage applied
options.C: Vomiting and discomfort is caused by traction due to exteriorization275
options.D: Adnexal exposure is low so tubal sterilization is difficult

questions.explanation: Adnexal exposure is high and hence tubal sterilization is easy.After delivery of the placenta, the uterus is lifted through the incision onto the draped abdominalwall. The fundus is covered with a moistened laparotomy sponge and this is known asexteriorisation of uterus.Benefits of exteriorization:• Relaxed, atonic uterus can be recognized quickly and massage applied.•The incision and bleeding points are more easily visualized and repaired.• Adnexal exposure is superior, and thus, tubal sterilization is easier.Drawbacks of exteriorization:• Intraoperative nausea and vomiting• Need for additional uterotonics• Longer time duration to the first recognized bowel movementThe below image shows the exteriorisation of the uterus.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication for peripartum hysterectomy?
questions.explanation: Cervical cancer is not an indication for peripartum hysterectomy.Indications for peripartum hysterectomy include:• Uterine atony - when every other method fails to control PPH• Uterine extension282• Uterine rupture• Postpartum uterine infection• Cervical laceration• Leiomyoma - large leiomyomas in a woman with completed family• Ovarian neoplasia

questions.question: What is the most common fetal injury associated with caesarean section?
questions.explanation: Skin laceration is the most common fetal injury associated with caesarean section. Other injuriesseen include:••CephalohematomaBrachial plexus injury• Clavicular fracture•Skull fracture• Facial nerve palsy

questions.question: An elective caesarean section is planned for a pregnant woman with a cardiac ailment. Whichof the following complications is she not at an increased risk for?
questions.explanation: Elective caesarean section decreases the risk of chorioamnionitis.Maternal complications increase with caesarean section when compared with vaginal deliveries.Some of these complications include:• Post-operative infection• Haemorrhage• Thromboembolism• Anaesthesia-related complications• Mendelson syndrome/ aspiration pneumonitis

questions.explanation: The given image shows a pneumatic compression device. It is used in women who are not on anythromboprophylaxis and planned for cesarean section (statement A) and it is discontinued oncethe patient starts ambulating post-surgery (statement C).The device is used because pregnancy and surgery increase the risk of thromboembolism.According to recent guidelines, patients with no additional risk factors and not placed on anypharmacological thromboprophylaxis are placed on pneumatic compression devices before283cesarean delivery. Patients undergoing cesarean delivery with additional risk factors are put onboth pneumatic compression devices and pharmacological therapy (UFH or LMWH).UFH-unfractionated heparin, LMWH-lower molecular weight heparin.•Indications of pharmacological thromboprophylaxis:• Inherited coagulation disorder• Overweight or obese patient.• Heart failure•Family history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism

questions.question: The risk factors for venous thromboembolism after caesarean section include allexcept
questions.explanation: Age >35 years is a risk factor for venous thromboembolism after caesarean section. The otherrisk factors include:•••Emergency cesareanObesityParity >3• Caesarean hysterectomy• Concurrent infection•Preeclampsia•• Prior deep-vein thrombosis or thrombophilia

questions.question: A 28-year-old multigravida with a history of C-section is being considered for vaginal delivery.The presence of which of the following features would categorise this procedure as low risk?
questions.explanation: Transverse incision in prior caesarean section is a low risk factor in vaginal birth after cesarean(VBAC).Risk factors for VBAC:High risk -• Classical or T-incision in prior cesarean• Prior rupture• Obstetrical contraindication such as placenta previa• Inadequate facilitiesLow risk• Transverse incision in prior cesarean• Prior vaginal delivery• Sufficient personnel and equipment284

questions.question: A trial of scar is performed on a G2P1L1 woman. The risk of which of the followingcomplications is increased in this baby when compared to their elder sibling?
questions.explanation: Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) in neonates has a higher incidence with trial of scaror VBAC as compared to elective cesarean.Uterine rupture is a dangerous complication of VBAC. This leads to hemorrhage which can causethe baby to be hypoxic eventually leading to permanent brain damage from hypoxic-ischemicencephalopathy. This results in developmental delay and cerebral palsy.Birth trauma, transient tachypnea of newborn (TTN) and neonatal sepsis are more commonlyseen with elective caesarean in comparison to VBAC.285
